rdf:Description.ns1:label: Typha latifolia
rdf:Description.ns1:abstract: Typha latifolia (broadleaf cattail, bulrush, common bulrush, common cattail, cat-o'-nine-tails, great reedmace, cooper's reed, cumbungi) is a perennial herbaceous plant in the genus Typha. It is found as a native plant species in North and South America, Eurasia, and Africa.
rdf:Description.ns1:habitat:
British Columbia , Canada British Columbia , Canada British Columbia Canada It is found as a native plant species in North and South America, Eurasia, and Africa.
In Canada, broadleaf cattail occurs in all provinces and also in the Yukon and Northwest Territories , and in the United States, it is native to all states except Hawaii .
It is an introduced and invasive species , and is considered a noxious weed in Australia and Hawaii.
It has been reported in Indonesia, Malaysia , New Zealand , Papua New Guinea , and the Philippines . It is referred to as Soli-soli in the Philippines.
native plant
Yukon Northwest Territories Hawaii
introduced invasive species noxious weed Australia
Malaysia New Zealand Papua New Guinea Philippines Soli-soli
The species has been found in a variety of climates, including tropical, subtropical, southern and northern temperate, humid coastal, and dry continental.
It is found at elevations from sea level to 2,300 metres (7,500 ft).
citation needed citation needed citation needed T. latifolia is an "obligate wetland" species, meaning that it is always found in or near water.
The species generally grows in flooded areas where the water depth does not exceed 0.8 m ( 2 + 1 ⁄ 2 ft),
but has also been reported growing in floating mats in slightly deeper water.
It grows mostly in fresh water but also occurs in slightly brackish marshes.
The species can displace other species native to salt marshes upon reduction in salinity. Under such conditions the plant may be considered aggressive since it interferes with preservation of the salt marsh habitat.
T. latifolia
2 + 1 ⁄ 2 + 1 2
T. latifolia shares its range with other related species, and hybridizes with Typha angustifolia , narrow-leaf cattail, to form Typha × glauca ( T. angustifolia × T. latifolia ), white cattail.
Common cattail is usually found in shallower water than narrow-leaf cattail.
T. latifolia Typha angustifolia Typha angustifolia Typha × glauca T. angustifolia × T. latifolia
